stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: 2016-INDICATOR3RQKX3
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: From submission: I initially noticed a spam incident where the sender was using my own email to send spam emails with links to a computer at stanford.edu. I received about 10-15 of these all from different originating IPs.

stix:TTP.ttp:Title: 2016-INDICATOR3RQKX3
stix:TTP.ttp:Description: I initially noticed a spam incident where the sender was using my own email to send spam emails with links to a computer at stanford.edu. I received about 10-15 of these all from different originating IPs.

stix:Incident.incident:Title: 2016-INDICATOR3RQKX3
stix:Incident.incident:Description:
I initially noticed a spam incident where the sender was using my own email to send spam emails with links to a computer at stanford.edu. I received about 10-15 of these all from different originating IPs. An example with the links to the stanford.edu server is below.
This triggered me to start trying to block spam on my exim based SMTP server. After several days of trying to find the root cause of the spam, I started simply blocking any SMTP connection that tried to phish for user accounts. I'm now at the point were I block any SMTP connection that does not send any data. It's apparent that there are numerous connection attempts from Asia, Latin America, and Europe that will simply connect to the server SMTP and not send any data. These same servers would also try other SMTP hacks to attempt to gain access to a user account.
The originating IPs will sometime cycle through a class-C network.

stix:Course_Of_Action.coa:Title: 2016-INDICATOR3RQKX3
stix:Course_Of_Action.coa:Description:
I initially noticed a spam incident where the sender was using my own email to send spam emails with links to a computer at stanford.edu. I received about 10-15 of these all from different originating IPs. An example with the links to the stanford.edu server is below.
This triggered me to start trying to block spam on my exim based SMTP server. After several days of trying to find the root cause of the spam, I started simply blocking any SMTP connection that tried to phish for user accounts. I'm now at the point were I block any SMTP connection that does not send any data. It's apparent that there are numerous connection attempts from Asia, Latin America, and Europe that will simply connect to the server SMTP and not send any data. These same servers would also try other SMTP hacks to attempt to gain access to a user account.
